EDITORIALS
WHY ABOLISH FOOTBALL?
Signing a petition stating that the undersigned believe that the abolishment of any competitive sport at the Johns Hopkins University would
be a detriment to the University undergraduate body, over two hundred
undergraduates took a stand diametricly opposed to that of Dean Berry
yesterday. At the assembly, student opinion voiced was almost unanimous in favoring the continuance of football. The only object voiced
was that if football were continued, no cage would be erected. No evidence was presented to substantiate this opinion. The reverse is nearer
the truth in our opinion. Football is a financial asset rather than a liability even at Hopkins. Certain alumni would not contribute to cage if
all intercollegiate athletics were abolished. We do not believe that the
abolitiOn of football would aid a cage drive in any way.
There seems to be much misunderstanding regarding the statement
of Dean Berry favoring the abolishment of football. The situation in
brief is as follows: President Ames appointed a committee to investigate physical education and athletics. One of the minor points suggested
to the committe was to consider football in general, not particularly as
at Hopkins. Dean Berry, as a member of the committee, made the
statement that he favored the abolishment of football. This does not
mean that football will be abolished. The opinions of the remainder
of the committee have not been officially given, but from the very
composition of the body, we believe that there is little or no chance of
these report containing a provision favoring the abolition of football.
We can see no reason why football, as it now is at Hopkins, should
be dropped. If football were commercialized at Hopkins to the extent
it is at some other institutions, there would be many arguments for taking this course. Athletes at Hopkins are neither paid nor favored. They
are not idolized on the campus or in the classroom. The only plausible
argument against football at Hopkins, is that the teams plays institutions which although inferior scholasticly are consistently better athleticly. A change of schedule would remedy this. It is reasonable to suppose that other universities will follow the movement at the University
of Pennsylvania and revise their athletic systems so as to keep football
from being overemphasized. Hopkins could probably schedule such
teams in the future. Football was dropped at Columbia in 1905 due to
the fact that too many injuries resulted from the game as played at that
date. Later, after the rules had been revised, it was found advisable to
resume the sport. Although the situations are not analogous, we believe
that if Hopkins were to drop football, it would find that for similar
reasons it would be advisable to again play the game. It was found at
Columbia that with the abolishment of football, all sports fell into
decay. The work of the committee appointed by Dr. Ames is to improve physical education and not to abolish sports.
An editorial appearing in one of the daily papers claiming the Board
of Trustees would be unwise to spend money on a cage, merely served
to show the ignorance of the writer. Everyone with any knowledge of
the situation at Hopkins knows that the Board of Trustees has never
seriously considered erecting the building. The board realizes that it is
in no financial position to make such an outlay at the present time. A
cage can be built if a competent committee solicits contributions from
the alumni after the undergraduates have clearly shown by their contributions that they need and want such a building.
In closing we would like to repeat that we can see no reason why
the abolishment of football Is it is at Hopkins would aid any program
of physical education, or why football and inter-rural athletics cannot
go hand in hand after the erection of the cage.

WHY ABOLISH FOOTBALL?
Signing a petition stating that the undersigned believe that the abolishment of any competitive sport at the Johns Hopkins University would
be a detriment to the University undergraduate body, over two hundred
undergraduates took a stand diametricly opposed to that of Dean Berry
yesterday. At the assembly, student opinion voiced was almost unanimous in favoring the continuance of football. The only object voiced
was that if football were continued, no cage would be erected. No evidence was presented to substantiate this opinion. The reverse is nearer
the truth in our opinion. Football is a financial asset rather than a liability even at Hopkins. Certain alumni would not contribute to cage if
all intercollegiate athletics were abolished. We do not believe that the
abolitiOn of football would aid a cage drive in any way.
There seems to be much misunderstanding regarding the statement
of Dean Berry favoring the abolishment of football. The situation in
brief is as follows: President Ames appointed a committee to investigate physical education and athletics. One of the minor points suggested
to the committe was to consider football in general, not particularly as
at Hopkins. Dean Berry, as a member of the committee, made the
statement that he favored the abolishment of football. This does not
mean that football will be abolished. The opinions of the remainder
of the committee have not been officially given, but from the very
composition of the body, we believe that there is little or no chance of
these report containing a provision favoring the abolition of football.
We can see no reason why football, as it now is at Hopkins, should
be dropped. If football were commercialized at Hopkins to the extent
it is at some other institutions, there would be many arguments for taking this course. Athletes at Hopkins are neither paid nor favored. They
are not idolized on the campus or in the classroom. The only plausible
argument against football at Hopkins, is that the teams plays institutions which although inferior scholasticly are consistently better athleticly. A change of schedule would remedy this. It is reasonable to suppose that other universities will follow the movement at the University
of Pennsylvania and revise their athletic systems so as to keep football
from being overemphasized. Hopkins could probably schedule such
teams in the future. Football was dropped at Columbia in 1905 due to
the fact that too many injuries resulted from the game as played at that
date. Later, after the rules had been revised, it was found advisable to
resume the sport. Although the situations are not analogous, we believe
that if Hopkins were to drop football, it would find that for similar
reasons it would be advisable to again play the game. It was found at
Columbia that with the abolishment of football, all sports fell into
decay. The work of the committee appointed by Dr. Ames is to improve physical education and not to abolish sports.
An editorial appearing in one of the daily papers claiming the Board
of Trustees would be unwise to spend money on a cage, merely served
to show the ignorance of the writer. Everyone with any knowledge of
the situation at Hopkins knows that the Board of Trustees has never
seriously considered erecting the building. The board realizes that it is
in no financial position to make such an outlay at the present time. A
cage can be built if a competent committee solicits contributions from
the alumni after the undergraduates have clearly shown by their contributions that they need and want such a building.
In closing we would like to repeat that we can see no reason why
the abolishment of football Is it is at Hopkins would aid any program
of physical education, or why football and inter-rural athletics cannot
go hand in hand after the erection of the cage.
